"Correct" is used instead of "yes" or "right" because it provides clarity and precision in communication. In safety-critical environments like railway operations, ambiguity can lead to misunderstandings that may result in operational delays or safety incidents. "Correct" is universally understood and less likely to be misheard over radio communication, ensuring that the intended message is accurately conveyed and acknowledged.
